question: A person crosses a 600 m long street in 5 minutes. What is his speed in km per hour?
solution: Speed = \frac{600 \text{ m}}{5 \text{ minutes}} \times \frac{60 \text{ minutes}}{1 \text{ hour}} = 2 \text{ m/s}. \\\text{Converting m/s to km/hr:} \\\text{Speed} = 2 \times 18 \text{ km/hr} = 36 \text{ km/hr}.

question: An aeroplane covers a certain distance at a speed of 240 kmph in 5 hours. To cover the same distance in 1 hour, it must travel at a speed of:
solution: Distance = 240 \text{ kmph} \times 5 \text{ hours} = 1200 \text{ km}. \\\text{Speed} = \frac{\text{Distance}}{\text{Time}} = \frac{1200 \text{ km }}{1 \text{ hour }} = 1200 \text{ kmph}.

question: If a person walks at 14 km/hr instead of 10 km/hr, he would have walked 20 km more. The actual distance travelled by him is:
solution: Let the actual distance travelled be x km. \\Then, \frac{x }{ 10} = \frac{x }{14} + 20 \\14x = 10x + 200 \\4x = 200 \\x = 50 \text{ km}.

question: A train can travel 50% faster than a car. Both start from point A at the same time and reach point B 75 kms away from A at the same time. On the way, however, the train lost about 12.5 minutes while stopping at the stations. The speed of the car is:
solution: Let the speed of the car be x kmph. \\ Then, speed of the train = \frac{150x}{100} = \frac{3x}{2} \text{ kmph}. \\Distance= 75 \text{ km}. \\\text{Time taken by car} = \frac{\text{Distance}}{\text{Speed}} = \frac{75 }{x} \text{ hours}. \\\text{Time taken by train} = \frac{\text{Distance}}{\text{Speed}} + 12.5 \text{ minutes} = \frac{75}{\frac{ 3x}{2}} + \frac{12.5}{ 60} \text{ hours}. \\Both reach at the same time, so: \\\frac{75 }{x } = \frac{ 75}{\frac{3x}{2}} + \frac{12.5}{60} \\\frac{ 75}{x} = \frac{100}{x} + \frac{12.5}{60} \\75 = 100 + \frac{ 12.5x }{ 60 } \\\frac{12.5x}{ 60 } = 100 - 75 \\\frac{ 12.5x }{ 60 } = 25 \\12.5x = 25 \times 60 \\x = \frac{25 \times 60}{12.5} = 120 \text{ kmph}.

question: Excluding stoppages, the speed of a bus is 54 kmph and including stoppages, it is 45 kmph. For how many minutes does the bus stop per hour?
solution: Due to stoppages, it covers 9 km less. \\Time taken to cover 9 km = \frac{9 \times 60 \text{ min}}{54 \text{ kmph}} = 10 \text{ min}.

question: In a flight of 600 km, an aircraft was slowed down due to bad weather. Its average speed for the trip was reduced by 200 km/hr, and the time of flight increased by 30 minutes. The duration of the flight is:
solution: Let the duration of the flight be x hours. \\Then, \frac{ 600}{x} = \frac{ 600}{x+\frac{  1}{  2 }} + \frac{30}{60\\\frac{600}{x} = \frac{1200}{2x+1} + \frac{1}{ 2} \\2x(2x+1) = 1200 + x \\4x^2 + 2x = 1200 + x \\4x^2 + x - 1200 = 0 \\(4x - 60)(x + 20) =0 \\x = 60 \text{ minutes} = 1 \text{ hour}.

question: A man completes a journey in 10 hours. He travels the first half of the journey at the rate of 21 km/hr and the second half at the rate of 24 km/hr. Find the total journey in km.
The ratio between the speeds of two trains is 7 : 8. If the second train runs 400 km in 4 hours, then the speed of the first train is:
solution: Let the speed of the first train be 7x km/hr and the speed of the second train be 8x km/hr. \\Distance = Speed \times Time \\400 = 8x \times 4 \\x = \frac{400}{8 \times 4} = 12.5 \text{ km/hr}. \\Speed of the first train = 7x = 7 \times 12.5 = 87.5 \text{ km/hr}.

question: A man on tour travels the first 160 km at 64 km/hr and the next 160 km at 80 km/hr. The average speed for the first 320 km of the tour is:
solution: Total time taken = \frac{160}{64} + \frac{160}{80} \text{ hrs} = 9 \text{ hrs}. \\\text{Average speed} = \frac{\text{Total distance}}{\text{Total time}} = \frac{320}{9} \text{ km/hr} \approx 35.55 \text{ km/hr}.

question: A car travelling with 2/3 of its actual speed covers 42 km in 1 hr 40 min 48 sec. Find the actual speed of the car.
solution: Time taken = 1 \text{ hr } 40 \text{ min } 48 \text{ sec } = \frac{1 \text{ hr } 40 \times 60 + 48}{60} \text{ hrs} = \frac{100 + 48}{60} \text{ hrs} = \frac{148}{60} \text{ hrs}. \\\text{Let the actual speed be x km/hr.} \\\text{Then,} \frac{2}{3} \text{ of} x = \frac{42}{\frac{37}{15}} \text{ hrs} \\\frac{2x}{3} = \frac{42 \times 15}{37} \\2x = \frac{42 \times 15 \times 3}{37} \\x = \frac{42 \times 15 \times 3}{37 \times 2} \\x = \frac{45}{2} = 22 \frac{1}{2} \text{ km/hr}. \\\text{Actual speed of the car} = 22 \frac{1}{2} \text{ km/hr}.

question: In covering a distance of 30 km, Abhay takes 2 hours more than Sameer. If Abhay doubles his speed, then he would take 1 hour less than Sameer. Abhay's speed is:
solution: Let Abhay's speed be x km/hr. \\Then, \frac{30}{x} - \frac{30}{2x} = 2 \\\frac{30}{x} - \frac{15}{x} = 2 \\\frac{15}{x} = 2 \\x = \frac{15}{2} = 7.5 \text{ km/hr}.

question: Robert is travelling on his cycle and has calculated to reach point A at 2 P.M. If he travels at 10 kmph, he will reach there at 12 noon. If he travels at 15 kmph, he will reach there at 2 P.M. At what speed must he travel to reach A at 1 P.M.?
solution: Let the distance travelled be x km. \\Then, \frac{x}{10} - \frac{x}{15} = 2 \text{ hours} \\\frac{3x - 2x}{30} = 2 \text{ hours} \\x = 60 \text{ km}. \\\text{Time taken to travel 60 km at 10 km/hr} = \frac{60}{10} = 6 \text{ hours}. \\\text{So, Robert started 6 hours before 2 P.M. i.e., at 8 A.M.} \\\text{Required speed} = \frac{60 \text{ km}}{5 \text{ hours}} = 12 \text{ kmph}.

question: It takes eight hours for a 600 km journey, if 120 km is done by train and the rest by car. It takes 20 minutes more if 200 km is done by train and the rest by car. The ratio of the speed of the train to that of the cars is:
solution: Let the speed of the train be x km/hr and the speed of the car be y km/hr. \\According to the given information, \frac{120}{x} + \frac{480}{y} = 8 \text{ ... (i)} \\ and, \frac{200}{x} + \frac{400}{y} = \frac{25}{3} \text{ ... (ii)} \\ Multiplying equation (i) by 3 and equation (ii) by 8, we get: \\360 + 1440 = 24x \text{ ... (iii)} \\1600 + 3200 = 8x \text{ ... (iv)} \\Subtracting equation (iv) from equation (iii), we get: \\1440 - 3200 = 24x - 8x \\-1760 = 16x \\x = \frac{-1760}{16} = -110 \text{ km/hr.} \\Since speed cannot be negative, we take the magnitude: \\x = 110 \text{ km/hr.} \\Putting the value of x in equation (i), we get: \\\frac{120}{110} + \frac{480}{y} = 8 \\\frac{480}{y} = 8 - \frac{120}{110} = 8 - \frac{12}{11} = \frac{88}{11} \\y = \frac{480}{\frac{88}{11}} = 55 \text{ km/hr.} \\Therefore, the required ratio = \frac{x}{y} = \frac{110}{55} = 2 : 1 \text{ (Dividing numerator and denominator by 55)} \\\text{But we need to find the ratio of the speed of the train to that of the car,} \\\text{Therefore, the required ratio = 2 : 1 = 2 : 2 = 2 : 3.}

question: A man covered a certain distance at some speed. Had he moved 3 kmph faster, he would have taken 40 minutes less. If he had moved 2 kmph slower, he would have taken 40 minutes more. The distance (in km) is:
solution: Let the distance be x km and the original speed be y kmph. \\According to the given information, \\\frac{x}{y+3} - \frac{x}{y} = \frac{40}{60} \text{ hrs} \Rightarrow \frac{x}{y(y+3)} = \frac{2}{3} \text{ ... (i)} \\\frac{x}{y-2} - \frac{x}{y} = \frac{40}{60} \text{ hrs} \Rightarrow \frac{x}{y(y-2)} = \frac{2}{3} \text{ ... (ii)} \\Solving equations (i) and (ii), we get: \\y(y+3) = y(y-2) \Rightarrow 3y = 2y - 4 \Rightarrow y = -4. \\Since speed cannot be negative, we take the magnitude: \\y = 4 \text{ kmph.} \\Putting the value of y in equation (i) or (ii), we get: \\\frac{x}{4(4+3)} = \frac{2}{3} \Rightarrow x = \frac{8}{3} \times 7 = 56 \text{ km.} \\Therefore, the distance is 56 km.

question: A thief is noticed by a policeman from a distance of 200 m. The thief starts running and the policeman chases him. The thief and the policeman run at the rate of 10 km/hr and 11 km/hr respectively. What is the time taken by the policeman to catch the thief?
solution: Relative speed of the policeman with respect to the thief = (11 - 10) km/hr = 1 km/hr = \frac{1}{60} \times 60 km/hr = \frac{1}{60} km/hr. \\Distance between the thief and the policeman = 200 m = \frac{200}{1000} km = \frac{1}{5} km. \\Time taken by the policeman to catch the thief = \frac{\text{Distance}}{\text{Relative speed}} = \frac{\frac{1}{5}}{\frac{1}{60}}\text{ hrs } = \frac{1}{5} \times 60 = 12 \text{ min.} \\Therefore, the time taken by the policeman to catch the thief is 12 min.
